Answer: Data Scientists are people with some mix of coding and statistical skills who work on making data useful in various ways. In my world, there are two main types:Type A Data Scientist:Data Scientists are people with some mix of coding and statistical skills who work on making data useful in various ways. In my world, there are two main types:Type A Data Scientist:The Type A Data Scientist can code well enough to work with data but is not necessarily an expert. The Type A data scientist may be an expert in experimental design, forecasting, modeling, statistical inference, or other things typically taught in statistics departments. Generally speaking though, the work product of a data scientist is not "p-values and confidence intervals" as academic statistics sometimes seems to suggest (and as it sometimes is for traditional statisticians working in the pharmaceutical industry, for example). At Google, Type A Data Scientists are known variously as Statistician, Quantitative Analyst, Decision Support Engineering Analyst, or Data Scientist, and probably a few more.Type B Data Scientist:At Google, a Type B Data Scientist would typically be called a Software Engineer. Type B Data Scientists may use the term Data Scientist to refer just to themselves, and since the definition of the field is very much in flux, they may be right. But I see the term being used most often in the general way I am proposing here.This categorization is crude. Many Data Scientists are some mix of A and B. But this answer is long enough already.

Tell me how that flies.For example…As far as race goes…As far as religion goes…As far as gender identity goes…Age is just a number, and it is a protected characteristic. Please stop perpetuating stereotypes, and condoning the use of them to gather “tricks” for teaching.AssessiThere are noInsert any other human attribute, characteristic, descriptor that some people use to pigeon-hole people and paint people with broad brush strokes. Tell me how that flies.For example…As far as race goes…As far as religion goes…As far as gender identity goes…Age is just a number, and it is a protected characteristic. Generations are random blocks of time. Please stop perpetuating stereotypes, and condoning the use of them to gather “tricks” for teaching.Assessing learner needs is assessing learner needs. Good facilitation is good facilitation. Stop searching for tricks and start focusing on learners as they are - unique individuals with different experiences.Editing to add…Using tech in the classroom just for the sake of using tech because your students use tech is back-assward instructional design.Editing to add an aside…Ties to technology? At the risk of sounding like my dad, I need to say some things about my experience with technology, which is only a fraction of what many of my peers were doing.I was writing papers on an Apple IIe word processor, before my son was even a passing thought. My very first job out of undergrad was coordinating service appointments and inventory for a pc repair company, and the summer before that, I was working on a PC and a Mac (where people my dad’s age were writing, testing and implementing proprietary software). I knew the insides of a PC before most people were even using them at home. I helped hundreds of adults transition from DOS to Windows. I was one of the beta testersfor Windows 95 (the first time the MS Windows GUI resembled the Mac, with a trash can to delete and visible file & folder organization and drag/drop to move and copy those files)… I can keep going up to present day, but I think I have painted enough of the picture.
